A cyber war is already raging in China over the issue of Tibet.
In recent weeks, advocacy groups, activists and foreign journalists have been targeted by increasingly sophisticated computer attacks.
As NPR's Anthony Kuhn reports from Beijing, it's a covert form of warfare being waged by shadowy aggressors.
Last week at the Hong Kong Airport, local authorities barred several members of the New York-based group Students for a Free Tibet from entering the territory.
They were there to protest the Olympic torch relay.
Nathan Dorjee is a volunteer computer consultant to the group.
He thinks this could have been related to some emails the group recently received.
A number of our board members and staff were on the list that received what was essentially an email from a former board member that said, hey, everyone, how are you?
Here's a resume that I have for someone I think you should hire.
And then if you had clicked on the resume, it was a Word file that had a virus in it and you would have been infected.
This malicious software is called a Trojan.
Mikko Hypponen is chief researcher for F-Secure, an anti-virus company based in Helsinki, Finland.
The machines that get infected will secretly and invisibly start to report everything that's being done on the computer to the order of the Trojan.
For example: records every single key stroke from your keyboard, provides full access to every file on your computer and even worse, provides full access to every single file in your network.
The attacks increased after the unrest in Tibet in mid-March.
But even before that, groups such as Human Rights in China, the Falun Gong spiritual movement, and some China-based foreign journalists were receiving the emails.
Hypponen says these Trojans are sophisticated pieces of programming that are usually targeted at governments and large corporations.
They can defeat most anti-virus software and they use a technique known as social engineering.
Social engineering means using psychology to convince people to open up the attachment.
The email you receive looks like it's coming from someone you know - your workmate, your relative.
The information that the Trojans steal from computers is often sent to Internet servers in China.
But Hypponen points out that from there the information can be routed to any computer in the world, so there's no concrete evidence linking the attacks to China.
Whatever is the case, I will refuse to go on record saying that this is the Chinese.
I do believe I have enough problems already.
Cyber saboteurs are also targeting Chinese Web sites.
Wasai.com(ph) is a Chinese Web site that started a campaign to express patriotism by putting little red heart emoticons in front of instant messages so as to say I love China.
(Foreign language spoken)
Nathan Dorjee says that the cyber attacks are an extension of greater conflicts being waged in the real world.
It really, for us, it mirrors a protest on the street.
You see Tibetans simply trying to have a voice and being shut down, either by a government or by pro-China nationalists.
What we see online is the same thing.
